Description: Ovoid weight with a flat base, in light material, likely plaster (limestone of poor quality?); surface painted in red; standard of weight difficult to define since the weight was reconstructed from different fragments with a lot of glue.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Oriental Institute, University of Chicago. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Teardrop, or ovoid, weights are rare in Naukratis as in Egypt in general (Petrie 1886, pl. XXIII; Cour-Marty 1990, 26, fig. 8, fig. 13 and fig. 26). They appear to be more numerous in the New Kingdom than in later periods (Cour-Marty 1990, fig. 26). These weights are usually associated to the Egyptian standard deben-kedet around 9g, or to lighter unit around 8g which could correspond to other standards such as the Near Eastern shekel or the Greek stater (Cour-Marty 1990, 24-25, fig. 22-24; Kroll 2003, 317; van Alfen 2002, 184, n. 654). In the case of this weight, its state of conservation does not allow identifying properly the standard used. However, the fact that it is made of a light painted material - maybe to copy some hard heavier stones, it is possible that this is a false weight, made to deceive customers. For a normal teardrop weight in light red stone: Chicago, Oriental Institute, University of Chicago E2882. Cour-Marty, M.-A. 1989.
